Well, I've been discussing all your comments with my colleagues, and 
I'm p=
lanning to try changing things in the next piece of work I'm now 
starting.=
 I'll try extracting out code that "doesn't belong" into other 
classes, an=
d refactoring the big methods into smaller, more testable 
chunks, and so o=
n. I think that doing this in even one or two classes 
may well cut down on=
 a lot of the testing, and a lot of the Mocking, 
too. Thanks everyone for =
your help on this!


But I was also thinking about how we are using mocks a=
nd JMock... 
Using this tool demands that you define how each of the method=
s called 
on a mocked object behave. For a given method, you define what it=
 will 
return, and specify that you expect it to be called once, or twice, =
or 
that you don't care if it's called or not, and say what parameters you =

expect. 
So, from the JUnit point of view, this means that we can test wha=
t will 
happen if the mock's method returns null, or an exception, or the t=
hing 
we expect, and so on. Whis is good, 'cos to get to this result 
other=
wise could be hard, especially if it's a database you're talking 
to.
But t=
he other point of this, as I understand it, is to test that the 
route you'=
re taking through your code is the one you expect to take. 
Now, this is wh=
ere some of the complexity comes in, because you have to 
define all the mo=
ck's method behaviour to support this, and even 
relatively minor changes t=
o the code can hit this hard. The mock's 
method name has changed, or you m=
oved some code which doesn't need to 
get executed in case of an exception,=
 or.... and so on. The result of 
the method you're testing is the same, bu=
t how you did it has changed. 
So the tests fail, as the methods you were e=
xpecting on the mock object 
now aren't called, and other ones are.

So, is=
 this kind of testing important enough to warrant all the effort 
it takes =
to write & keep up to date? 
Should we care what method got called on our m=
ock, or even whether it 
did get called at all? Or are we really only inter=
ested in the result 
of the main method we're testing?

Tracey
